Steppe people

In 9 CE the Roman poet Ovid arrived in Tomis, a town on the coast of the Black Sea. Ovid had been banished there by the emperor Augustus, for reasons that have never been clear. Back in Rome, Ovid had been celebrated and successful. But Tomis was a rustic outpost, an old Greek colony now occupied largely by barbarians called Getans. The townspeople didnâ€™t even speak Latin, the language of Romeâ€”none of them could understand, let alone appreciate, Ovidâ€™s poetry. To make matters worse, Tomis lay close to lands occupied by the Sarmatians, who raided the town and surrounding countryside frighteningly often
